Apple Scab: Apply fungicides like Myclobutanil or Sulfur from bud break through petal fall; rake and destroy fallen leaves in autumn to reduce spores.
Apple with Black Rot: Prune out dead wood, cankers, and 'mummified' fruit; apply protective fungicides (e.g., Captan or Sulfur) early in the growing season.
Cedar Apple Rust: Use preventative fungicides such as Myclobutanil or Propiconazole in spring; remove nearby juniper (alternate host) plants if possible.
Healthy Apple: Maintain an annual pruning schedule to improve air circulation and apply a balanced 10-10-10 fertilizer in early spring if growth is slow.
Healthy Blueberry Plant: Ensure soil pH is acidic (4.5–5.5) using elemental sulfur; provide consistent moisture and 2-3 inches of organic mulch like pine bark.
Cherry with Powdery Mildew: Apply sulfur-based fungicides or horticultural oils early in the morning; prune dense canopies to improve airflow and reduce humidity.
Healthy Cherry Plant: Ensure well-draining soil to prevent root rot and apply a dormant oil spray in late winter to control overwintering pests.
Corn (Maize) with Cercospora and Gray Le: Utilize crop rotation and tillage to bury infected residue; apply foliar fungicides (e.g., strobilurins or triazoles) if disease pressure is high.
Corn (Maize) with Common Rust: Usually requires no treatment in home gardens; for commercial crops, apply fungicides only if pustules appear on more than 10% of the leaf area.
Corn (Maize) with Northern Leaf Blight: Improve field drainage and use deep plowing to decompose old stalks; apply preventative fungicides at the 'tasseling' stage if conditions are wet.
Healthy Corn (Maize) Plant: Apply nitrogen-rich fertilizer (like CAN or Urea) when the plant is knee-high and ensure 1 inch of water weekly, especially during the critical tasseling stage.
Grape with Black Rot: Apply fungicides containing Myclobutanil or Mancozeb starting at 4-inch shoot growth; remove all 'mummified' berries from the vine and ground to eliminate overwintering spores.
Grape with Esca (Black Measles): There is no known chemical cure; manage by protecting pruning wounds with sealants (like B-Lock) and utilizing 'trunk renewal' or surgical curettage to remove decayed wood.
Grape with Isariopsis Leaf Spot: Use protective copper-based fungicides or Mancozeb during the growing season; maintain a thin canopy through leaf removal to reduce the humidity that favors fungal growth.
Healthy Grape Plant: Perform heavy dormant pruning in late winter to remove 90% of last year's growth; maintain a neutral soil pH (6.5–7.0) and mulch to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Orange with Citrus Greening: There is no known cure; manage by aggressively controlling the Asian Citrus Psyllid (the insect vector) using systemic insecticides and removing infected trees to prevent spread.
Peach with Bacterial Spot: Apply copper-based sprays or oxytetracycline during the growing season; choose resistant varieties for future planting and avoid overhead irrigation to keep foliage dry.
Healthy Peach Plant: Apply a dormant oil spray in late winter to kill scale and mite eggs; prune annually to a 'V' or 'open center' shape to maximize sunlight to the inner branches.
Bell Pepper with Bacterial Spot: Spray plants with a mixture of copper fungicide and Mancozeb; practice a 2-year crop rotation and ensure seeds are certified disease-free before planting.
Healthy Bell Pepper Plant: Maintain consistent soil moisture to prevent blossom end rot and provide a stakes or cages for support to keep ripening fruit off the ground.
Potato with Early Blight: Apply fungicides containing Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb; ensure plants have adequate nitrogen and avoid overhead watering to prevent spore splash.
Potato with Late Blight: Highly contagious. Apply specialized fungicides like Ridomil Gold immediately; destroy infected plants and tubers by burying or bagging them—do not compost.
Healthy Potato Plant: Ensure deep soil hilling to protect developing tubers from sunlight and pests; provide consistent moisture (1-2 inches per week) during the flowering stage.
Healthy Raspberry Plant: Prune 'floricanes' (spent two-year-old canes) to the ground in late winter; apply a thick layer of organic mulch to keep shallow roots cool and moist.
Healthy Soybean Plant: Monitor for Aphids and Japanese Beetles during the pod-filling stage; ensure soil contains proper Rhizobium bacteria for natural nitrogen fixation.
Squash with Powdery Mildew: Apply potassium bicarbonate or neem oil sprays at the first sign of white spots; ensure wide plant spacing for airflow and avoid high-nitrogen fertilizers which promote susceptible soft growth.
Strawberry with Leaf Scorch: Remove and destroy infected leaves; apply a copper-based fungicide in early spring and avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen during the fruiting season.
Healthy Strawberry Plant: Renovate beds after harvest by thinning plants to 6 inches apart; provide consistent water (avoiding the crown) and mulch with clean straw to keep berries off the soil.
Tomato with Bacterial Spot: Apply a copper-fungicide and Mancozeb tank mix; practice a 3-year rotation (avoiding peppers/potatoes in the same spot) and never work with plants when they are wet.
Tomato with Early Blight: Prune the lower 'sucker' leaves to prevent soil-borne spores from splashing up; apply Chlorothalonil or copper spray and use a heavy organic mulch around the base.
Tomato with Late Blight: Extremely destructive; apply fungicides containing Chlorothalonil or Copper immediately. If infection is widespread, pull and bag the entire plant to prevent wind-borne spread to the community.
Tomato with Leaf Mold: Increase greenhouse ventilation and reduce humidity below 85%; apply protective fungicides like Calcium Polysulfide and prune the center of the plant to maximize airflow.
Tomato with Septoria Leaf Spot: Remove infected lower leaves and apply copper-based fungicides; use organic mulch to create a barrier between the soil-borne spores and the plant's foliage.
Tomato with Spider Mites or Two-spotted: Spray the undersides of leaves with Insecticidal Soap or Neem Oil; increase humidity around the plant and blast foliage with a strong stream of water to dislodge the mites.
Tomato with Target Spot: Improve air circulation through staking and pruning; apply fungicides containing Azoxystrobin or Chlorothalonil when symptoms (concentric rings) first appear.
Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus: No cure exists; focus on controlling the Whitefly vector with yellow sticky traps or systemic insecticides, and remove infected plants to protect healthy neighbors.
Tomato Mosaic Virus: No cure; pull and destroy the plant immediately. Avoid tobacco use near plants (the virus can spread from smoker's hands) and sterilize all pruning tools with 10% bleach.
Healthy Tomato Plant: Provide consistent deep watering at the base (1-2 inches/week) to prevent blossom end rot; apply a balanced fertilizer and prune 'suckers' to focus energy on fruit production.
aphid: The easiest way to handle aphids is using soap and water. You can also try Neem oil and other essential oils.
scale_insect: You can remove them manually using gloves or by dabbing it with isopropyl alcohol.
fruit fly: You don't need to be concerned much with this one.
